key_points: A lawsuit seeking $100 million in damages was filed against the Oxford Community School District and its officials for a shooting at Oxford High School.
The shooting, carried out by a 15-year-old, resulted in the death of four students and injury of seven others, including a teacher.
The lawsuit accuses the school district's superintendent, principal, and other staff of failing to act on prior knowledge of the shooter's threatening behavior.
Riley Franz, 17, who was injured in the shooting, and her sister Bella, 14, are represented in the lawsuit.
The shooter's parents are charged with involuntary manslaughter for providing him with a gun and ignoring warning signs.
The lawsuit blames the school for assuring parents and students of safety despite knowing of the shooter's disturbing online activity.
Accusations include the school staff's failure to properly respond to Ethan Crumbley's threats of violence and ammunition search.
The lawsuit was filed by Michigan personal injury attorney Geoffrey Fieger.
The district has not responded to the lawsuit.
The lawsuit emphasizes that the shooting was 'entirely preventable' and criticizes the school's reassurances of safety.
